TypeSignature.Value: public sealed class ItemCollection : System.Windows.Data.CollectionView, System.Collections.IList, System.ComponentModel.ICollectionViewLiveShaping, System.ComponentModel.IEditableCollectionViewAddNewItem, System.ComponentModel.IItemProperties, System.Windows.IWeakEventListener

.class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit ItemCollection extends System.Windows.Data.CollectionView implements class System.Collections.ICollection, class System.Collections.IEnumerable, class System.Collections.IList, class System.ComponentModel.ICollectionViewLiveShaping, class System.ComponentModel.IEditableCollectionView, class System.ComponentModel.IEditableCollectionViewAddNewItem, class System.ComponentModel.IItemProperties, class System.Windows.IWeakEventListener

Docs.summary: Holds the list of items that constitute the content of an .

remarks.format:
## Remarks ItemCollection maintains a collection of items such as strings, objects, [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_xml](~/add/includes/tlasharptla-xml-md.md)] nodes, elements, and other collections. An <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl> uses the data in the ItemCollection to generate its content. If you want to aggregate more than one collection, assign a <xref:System.Windows.Data.CompositeCollection> to the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl.ItemsSource%2A> property of your <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl>.
Use either the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl.Items%2A> property or the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl.ItemsSource%2A> property to specify the collection that should be used to generate the content of your <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl>. When the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl.ItemsSource%2A> property is set, the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl.Items%2A> collection will be made read-only and fixed-size. This means that if you are using the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl.ItemsSource%2A> property, you cannot add, delete, or change items in the ItemCollection directly.
ItemCollection is a <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView> and therefore provides collection view functionalities, such as sorting, grouping, and filtering. For more information, see <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemCollection.SortDescriptions%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemCollection.Filter%2A>, and <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemCollection.GroupDescriptions%2A>.
For more information about collection views, see [Data Binding Overview](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
## Examples If you have an <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl>, such as a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ListBox> that has content, you can use the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl.Items%2A> property to access the ItemCollection, which is a view. Because it is a view, you can then use the view-related functionalities such as sorting, filtering, and grouping. Note that when ItemsSource is set, the view operations delegate to the view over the ItemsSource collection. Therefore, the ItemCollection supports sorting, filtering, and grouping only if the delegated view supported them.
The following example shows how to sort the content of a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ListBox> named `myListBox`. In this example, `Content` is the name of the property to sort by.
[!code-cs[ListBoxSort_snip#Sort](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/ListBoxSort_snip/Window1.xaml.cs#sort)] [!code-vb[ListBoxSort_snip#Sort](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/listboxsort_snip/window1.xaml.vb#sort)]
When you do this, the view might or might not be the default view, depending on how the data is set up on your <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl>. For example, when the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl.ItemsSource%2A> property is bound to a <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionViewSource>, the view that you obtain using the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl.Items%2A> property is not the default view.
If your <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl> is bound (you are using the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl.ItemsSource%2A> property), then you can do the following to get the default view:
[!code-cs[GroupingSample#MyView](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/GroupingSample/Window1.xaml.cs#myview)] [!code-vb[GroupingSample#MyView](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/groupingsample/window1.xaml.vb#myview)] [!code-cs[GroupingSample#GetView](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/GroupingSample/Window1.xaml.cs#getview)] [!code-vb[GroupingSample#GetView](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/groupingsample/window1.xaml.vb#getview)]
Alternately, you can specify filtering, sorting, and grouping criteria in [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_xaml](~/add/includes/tla2sharptla-xaml-md.md)] using <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionViewSource>.

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the collection view supports turning filtering data in real time on or off.
Docs.value: if the collection view supports turning live filtering on or off; otherwise, .

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the collection view supports turning grouping data in real time on or off.
Docs.value: if the collection view supports turning live grouping on or off; otherwise, .

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the collection view supports turning sorting data in real time on or off.
Docs.value: if the collection view supports turning live sorting on or off; otherwise, .

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether this collection view supports filtering.
Docs.value: if this view supports filtering; otherwise, . The default value is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks Use this property to check whether this collection supports filtering before assigning a filter callback to the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemCollection.Filter%2A> property.

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether this collection view supports grouping.
Docs.value: if the collection supports grouping; otherwise, . The default value is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks Use this property to test whether the current implementation supports grouping before using the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemCollection.GroupDescriptions%2A> property to add <xref:System.ComponentModel.GroupDescription> objects.

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether this collection view supports sorting.
Docs.value: if this view support sorting; otherwise, . The default value is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks Use this property to check whether this collection supports sorting before using the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemCollection.SortDescriptions%2A> property to add <xref:System.ComponentModel.SortDescription> objects.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void Clear() cil managed

Docs.summary: Clears the collection and releases the references on all items currently in the collection.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following example shows how to use this method. In the example, `sbar` is a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.StatusBar> control, which is an <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl>.
[!code-vb[StatusBar#MakeProgressBar](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/statusbar/window1.xaml.vb#makeprogressbar)] [!code-cs[StatusBar#MakeProgressBar](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/StatusBar/Window1.xaml.cs#makeprogressbar)]

Docs.exception: The is in <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl.ItemsSource%2A> mode. (When the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl.ItemsSource%2A> property is set, the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl.Items%2A> collection will be made read-only and fixed-size.)

Gets the number of records in the collection.
Docs.value: The number of items in the collection or 0 if the collection is uninitialized or if there is no collection in the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl.ItemsSource%2A> mode.

Docs.summary: Gets the current item in the view.
Docs.value:
The current object in the view or if the collection is uninitialized or if there is no collection in the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl.ItemsSource%2A> mode.
By default, the first item of the collection starts as the current item.

Docs.summary: Gets the ordinal position of the current item within the view.
Docs.value: The ordinal position of the current item within the view or -1 if the collection is uninitialized or if there is no collection in the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl.ItemsSource%2A> mode.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig virtual instance class System.IDisposable DeferRefresh() cil managed

Docs.summary: Enters a defer cycle that you can use to merge changes to the view and delay automatic refresh.
Docs.returns: An <xref:System.IDisposable> object that you can use to dispose of the calling object.

remarks.format: ## Remarks This method is typically used to create a `using` scope and then place multiple view-changing calls within the scope. This delays automatic refresh until the defer cycle is exited.

MemberSignature.Value: public override Predicate<object> Filter { get; set; }

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a callback used to determine if an item is suitable for inclusion in the view.
Docs.value: A method used to determine if an item is suitable for inclusion in the view.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemCollection.CanFilter%2A> property to test whether the current implementation supports filtering before assigning this property with a non-null value.
## Examples For a related example, see [How to: Filter Data in a View](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).

remarks.format: ## Remarks This method evaluates the index with any sorting, filtering, or grouping criteria that are set on the view using the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.SortDescriptions%2A> or <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.Filter%2A> property.

Docs.summary: Gets a collection of objects that defines how to group the items.
Docs.value: An <xref:System.Collections.ObjectModel.ObservableCollection%601> of objects. The collection is indexed by the group levels.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemCollection.CanGroup%2A> property to test whether the current implementation supports grouping before adding <xref:System.ComponentModel.GroupDescription> objects.
> [!NOTE] > This property can be set only by accessing the collection object and using its various methods, such as `Add`. The property to access the collection object is read-only, while the collection itself is read-write.
## Examples For a related example, see <xref:System.Windows.Data.PropertyGroupDescription>.

Docs.summary: Gets the top-level groups that are constructed according to the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemCollection.GroupDescriptions%2A>.
Docs.value: The top-level groups that are constructed according to the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemCollection.GroupDescriptions%2A>. The default value is .

## Remarks Use the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemCollection.CanSort%2A> property to test whether the current implementation supports sorting before adding <xref:System.ComponentModel.SortDescription> objects to the <xref:System.ComponentModel.SortDescriptionCollection>.
> [!NOTE] > This property can be set only by accessing the collection object and using its various methods, such as `Add`. The property to access the collection object is read-only, while the collection itself is read-write.

Docs.summary: Gets a collection that contains information about the properties that are available on the items in a collection.

remarks.format: ## Remarks This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemCollection> instance is cast to an <xref:System.ComponentModel.IItemProperties> interface.
